schema_place.name: Bigelow Mountain - West Peak
schema_place.description: Bigelow Mountain - West Peak is a 4,145 foot peak in Maine offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Bigelow Mountain - West Peak?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Bigelow Mountain - West Peak take 5-7 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 10.8 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Bigelow Mountain - West Peak hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Bigelow Mountain - West Peak is rated Hard. At 4,145 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Bigelow Mountain - West Peak?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Bigelow Mountain - West Peak. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Bigelow Mountain - West Peak?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Fire Warden's Trail, offering Classic route to Bigelow Col, then traverse to both peaks..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Bigelow Mountain - West Peak?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Bigelow Mountain - West Peak is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,145 feet, Bigelow Mountain - West Peak ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footersa collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Fire Warden's Trail**, covers 10.8 miles and is rated Hard. Classic route to Bigelow Col, then traverse to both peaks.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Bigelow Mountain - Avery Peak lies just 0.5 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
Winter conditions in effect - full mountaineering gear required
Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
